results.abstract: International Space Station, which was to be finished by 2004 at cost of $40 billion collectively for 16 nations involved, is still not completed and will likely cost over $100 billion before it is done; these delays and changes in NASA initiatives have left many scientists wondering if project will ever become global space research center once envisioned; many in US space program say that station needs to be conducting vigorous research to find ways to counteract harmful effects of extended space travel; NASA is currently working toward missions on Moon and to Mars; general construction plans and roadblocks to completing International Space Station described; photos; drawing (M)

headline.main: Destination Is the Space Station, But Many Experts Ask What For

results.snippet: A question that has long been the subject of sharp debate among experts remains: What is the International Space Station for?

multimedia.caption: Space Station Status
multimedia.credit: Assembly of the International Space Station resumed in December after the launch of the space shuttle Discovery.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Assembly of the International Space Station resumed in December after the launch of the space shuttle Discovery.

results.lead_paragraph: Once again, the shuttle Discovery is about to blast into space. And once again, it will dock with the International Space Station, and astronauts will continue the process of building the half-completed orbiting laboratory in a mission full of daunting challenges. But the majesty of the first nighttime liftoff in more than four years, now scheduled for Thursday just before 9:36 p.m. Eastern time, will not dispel a question that has long been the subject of sharp debate among experts: What is the space station for?

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery will begin complex 11-day round trip to International Space Station, beginning with first nighttime launch in four years; if weather and technology cooperate, fiery blastoff should be visible along much of Eastern Seabord (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Set for Complex Trip to the Station

results.snippet: The space shuttle Discovery is to begin a complex 11-day round trip to the International Space Station as early as Thursday night, lighting up the skies in the first nighttime launching in four years.     If the weather and technology cooperate, the...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery is to begin a complex 11-day round trip to the International Space Station as early as Thursday night, lighting up the skies in the first nighttime launching in four years. If the weather and technology cooperate, the shuttle and its crew of seven astronauts will be launched just before 9:36 p.m. The fiery blastoff should be visible along much of the Eastern Seaboard; weather permitting, even New Yorkers will be able to see it along the south-southwest horizon about seven minutes after liftoff.

results.abstract: Launch of space shuttle Discovery may be postponed because of low clouds (M)

headline.main: Clouds May Delay Plans to Launch Space Shuttle Today

results.snippet: Low clouds related to a cold front have increased the likelihood that scheduled launching of the shuttle Discovery will be postponed, NASA said.
results.lead_paragraph: Low clouds related to a cold front have increased the likelihood that the scheduled launching of the shuttle Discovery on Thursday will have to be postponed at least a day, NASA said Wednesday. ''Unfortunately, the weather continues to deteriorate,'' said the shuttle launching weather officer, Katherine A. Winters.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery lifts off in first nighttime launching in more than four years; is on complex mission to reconfigure International Space Station's electrical system to receive power from new solar arrays and install stubby extension to structure; mission also includes tricky effort to coax one existing solar array into more compact form so new array can rotate to face sun continuously; photo (M)

headline.main: Discovery Takes Off on a Complex Mission

results.snippet: In the first nighttime launching in more than four years, the shuttle began a mission of space station rewiring.

multimedia.caption: The Night Launching of Discovery
multimedia.credit: In the first nighttime launching in more than four years, the shuttle began a mission of space station rewiring.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: In the first nighttime launching in more than four years, the shuttle began a mission of space station rewiring.

results.lead_paragraph: Night became day on Saturday as the shuttle Discovery muscled its way off of the launching pad with a shuddering roar on a mission to rewire the International Space Station. With a blinding streak of yellow flame that left a mark on the retina and a lump in the throat, the shuttle and its crew of seven astronauts lifted off at 8:47 p.m. in the program's first nighttime launching in more than four years.

results.abstract: Astronauts use International Space Station's robotic arm to examine spot on shuttle Discovery's left wing where sensors detected 'very low' vibration; NASA officials have not determined significance of finding, although they do not expect it to affect mission (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Docks; Spot on Wing Is Examined

results.snippet: Upon arriving, crews prepared to examine the outer side of the shuttle’s left wing, where sensors detected a “very low” impact, a NASA official said.
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts used the International Space Station's robotic arm on Monday to examine a spot on the shuttle Discovery's left wing where sensors detected a ''very low'' vibration, NASA officials said. ''It looks like something happened,'' said John P. Shannon, chairman of the mission management team, noting that the wing looked fine during an inspection earlier Monday. The sensor recorded a level of vibration not considered worrisome, Mr. Shannon said, but managers decided to take a closer look to be safe.

results.abstract: Astronauts from space shuttle Discovery encounter problems folding older solar array to make way for new rotating panels to power International Space Station; managers decide to leave array partially retracted for moment so astronauts can carry out rewiring process; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Crew Meets Obstacle in Rewiring

results.snippet: An array of solar panels that stubbornly refused to fold back into their box threatened to derail an attempt to rewire the International Space Station.
results.lead_paragraph: A balky array of solar panels that stubbornly refused to fold back into their box threatened yesterday to derail the ambitious attempt by NASA to rewire the International Space Station. The 12-day mission of the shuttle Discovery involves a complex and highly choreographed effort to alter the electrical system of the station from its current configuration, with power being drawn from a set of solar arrays atop the station, to a new arrangement that will draw power from an array that was taken up on the previous mission.

results.abstract: Maj. Arnold Strong tells the story of an American citizen-soldier in an all-night battle in the Afghan mountains.
results.snippet: Maj. Arnold Strong tells the story of an American citizen-soldier in an all-night battle in the Afghan mountains.
results.lead_paragraph: United States Army First Lt. Shawn Hammond is not your typical junior infantry officer. He is a big man, with a high forehead crowed with brown hair rapidly turning to salt and pepper. Having just turned 40, he has been a single father of three boys - aged 15, 14 and 8 - for years, although he remarried just before this deployment. He left active service over ten years ago, remaining in the Ready Reserve. After finishing his master's degree in psychology, Hammond attended law school with the goal of coming back in as a JAG (judge advocate general). However, after setting up a practice he did not return to the active reserve because he felt his civilian role as sole attorney for a battered women shelter in Augusta, Ga., assumed greater importance.

results.abstract: Two astronauts make complex six-hour spacewalk to rewire International Space Station which, for past six years, has been running on temporary configuration of its power system, drawing electricity from array of solar panels; rewiring brings station to its permanent arrangement; photo (M)

headline.main: 2 Spacewalkers Are Successful in Tricky Rewiring of the Space Station

results.snippet: At the midpoint of the mission of the shuttle Discovery, two astronauts took a complex six-hour spacewalk Thursday to rewire the International Space Station.
results.lead_paragraph: At the midpoint of the 12-day mission of the shuttle Discovery, two astronauts took a complex six-hour spacewalk yesterday to rewire the International Space Station. The spacewalkers, Capt. Robert L. Curbeam Jr. of the Navy and Christer Fuglesang of the European Space Agency, completed the tricky electrical work in just two hours and moved on to more mundane tasks before ending the spacewalk at 7:41 p.m., an hour ahead of schedule. They completed the first half of the rewiring, with a second spacewalk planned for Saturday to finish the job.

results.abstract: Capt Robert L Curbeam Jr is set to make repairs outside International Space Station; he became exposed to leaking ammonia while making repairs during spacewalk in 2001; photo (M)

headline.main: A Toxic Leak Haunts the Shuttle Crew

results.snippet: As he leads his third spacewalk today during the shuttle Discovery's mission to the International Space Station, one word is likely to be on Capt. Robert L. Curbeam Jr.'s mind: ammonia.      The foul-smelling chemical is used in the space station's...
results.lead_paragraph: As he leads his third spacewalk today during the shuttle Discovery's mission to the International Space Station, one word is likely to be on Capt. Robert L. Curbeam Jr.'s mind: ammonia. The foul-smelling chemical is used in the space station's cooling systems because its low freezing point is well suited to the chill of space.

results.abstract: Anita Gates reviews Carole Bugge play Strings, directed by Marvin Kaye; Mia Dillon and Warren Kelley star; photo (M)

headline.main: Infidelity, Shadowed by Six Scientists and Another Play

results.snippet: Carole Buggé’s play is an admirable, intelligent but ultimately unsuccessful drama.
results.lead_paragraph: Three scientists board a train to go to the play ''Copenhagen'' in London. En route they discuss various particles, concepts and theories, and a marital infidelity is revealed. This is the amusing if slightly strained premise of ''Strings,'' Carole Buggé's admirable, intelligent but ultimately unsuccessful drama, directed by Marvin Kaye. ''Strings,'' now at the 78th Street Theater Lab, has a star attraction: Keir Dullea. Almost four decades after he played his role of a lifetime, Dave the computer-killing astronaut in ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' Mr. Dullea is noticeably older, of course, but still very much the appealing leading man.

results.abstract: Two astronauts from space shuttle Discovery use jury-rigged tools to coax balky solar panels to fold up into their containers on International Space Station; old solar array had to be retracted to make room for new one; photo (M)

headline.main: Astronauts on Spacewalk Succeed in Folding Solar Panels

results.snippet: Two astronauts used jury-rigged tools, ingenuity and muscle to coax balky solar panels to fold up into their containers on the International Space Station.

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ; Warren E. Leary contributed reporting

results.lead_paragraph: Two spacewalking astronauts used jury-rigged tools, ingenuity and muscle yesterday to coax balky solar panels to fold up into their containers on the International Space Station. The exacting effort took care of the major piece of unfinished business for this 12-day mission of the shuttle Discovery. With innumerable starts, stops and tweaks, Capt. Robert L. Curbeam Jr. of the Navy and Christer Fuglesang, a Swede from the European Space Agency, helped a set of arrays, which when fully extended stretched about 115 feet, fold themselves like pleated blinds and fit back into the ''blanket boxes'' in which they made the trip to space.

results.abstract: Shuttle Discovery lands at Kennedy Space Center in Florida after 13-day mission to rewire International Space Station; landing site was in question for much of day because of NASA's strict weather rules; photo (M)

headline.main: Clouds and Rain Give Way, and the Discovery Touches Down in Florida

results.snippet: The shuttle’s mission was complex as astronauts rewired the International Space Station so it could draw power from a new array of solar panels.

byline.original: By STEFANO S. COLEDAN and JOHN SCHWARTZ; Stefano S. Coledan reported from Cape Canaveral, Fla., and John Schwartz from New York. Andrew Pollack contributed reporting from Edwards Air Force Base, Calif

results.lead_paragraph: The shuttle Discovery returned to Earth at 5:32 p.m. Friday in a gentle sunset landing at the Kennedy Space Center here. ''Wheels stop,'' said the shuttle commander, Mark L. Polansky, as the Discovery rolled to a stop on the 15,000-foot runway. After returning a greeting from mission managers, he said, ''It's going to be a great holiday.''
